SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Single cases with hemispheric, cortical or subcortical, ischemic lesions presenting with rotational vertigo (RV), that challenge the notion of infratentorial or peripheral generation of RV have been published, but the incidence of this symptom in a larger series is unknown
The aim of this study was to investigate whether acute hemispheric cerebrovascular lesions cause vertiginous sensations with particular emphasis on RV
METHODS: A total of 112 consecutive stroke patients were assessed in a prospective single-center study over a 22-month inclusion period
Rotational or other vertiginous sensations were assessed using a structured 5-item questionnaire and patients with vertigo were further evaluated with Yardley's Vertigo Symptom Scale
All subjects underwent standard clinical neuro-ophthalmological and neuro-otological testing and data were correlated to imaging findings
RESULTS: RV was absent among our patients
Few subjects reported non-rotational vertiginous sensations with stroke onset
These were mainly right-hemispheric strokes with concomitant subcortical leukoaraiosis
CONCLUSION: In this case series we did not find any patients with spinning sensations which is supportive of the dogma that supratenotrial lesions do not cause RV
Certain hemispheric stroke patterns, however, may be related to non-rotational dizziness
